article.headline: Arkansas 85, Tulsa 73
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Tulsa basketball coach John Phillips says the pressure from Arkansas was too much Tuesday night. First-half mistakes by the Golden Hurricane (1-2) -- which hadn't played since a 63-54 victory Nov. 21 over Northwestern State -- included a missed dunk, 19 turnovers and a lane violation. Arkansas led 43-32 at intermission, and went on to an 85-73 victory. "We just turned the ball over too much in the first half," Phillips said. "We weren't able to handle the pressure tonight." Freshman Charles Thomas' 16 points sparked Arkansas. The victory gave the Razorbacks (5-0) their best season start since 1997, when they opened 8-0. With the victory, Arkansas has won nine of the last 10 against the Golden Hurricane and leads the series 34-25. The Razorbacks forced 27 turnovers by Tulsa and translated them into 32 points. "We wanted to put pressure on them and extend the defense," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. "Our offense was created from the defense." The Razorbacks connected on 30 of their 61 field goal attempts. Arkansas put Tulsa on the defensive with a strong offensive performance in the early minutes. Led by Thomas, Arkansas was particularly hot from the perimeter. "Coach had confidence in me and the players did too," Thomas said. "That's all you need. Just let it go and let it happen." Thomas was a force both inside the paint and on the perimeter as Arkansas fought to overcome a 30-point, 11-rebound game by Tulsa's Jarius Glenn. During the second half, Arkansas widened its lead to as much as 19 at one point, 72-53. After the two teams traded baskets in the opening minutes, Arkansas was able to establish a 10-point advantage after Eric Ferguson entered the game. Ferguson, asked by Razorback coach Stan Heath earlier this week if he wanted to start, told Heath he would prefer to come off the bench. When he did so Tuesday night, it sparked a 9-0 run that gave Arkansas a 22-12 advantage with 12:02 left before intermission. Ferguson scored 8 of the Razorbacks points during the spurt, burying consecutive three-pointers. He finished the game with 11 points. Tulsa responded with an 8-0 run of its own, whittling the deficit down to just 2 points, 22-20. Arkansas held on to the lead, however, with Ferguson hitting another three-pointer to re-establish a 5-point margin. The Razorbacks then turned to their transition game to generate points. Ferguson launched an alley-oop pass to Ronnie Brewer, who tipped it in to give Arkansas a 34-23 lead. Moments after Dontell Jefferson hit a three-pointer, he picked off an errant Tulsa pass and fed the ball to Brewer, who streaked to the basket for a dunk that gave Arkansas a 40-32 lead. "We knew we had to put a lot of pressure on them," said Brewer, who scored 14 points. "We still have to get better though. This game gave us a lot of confidence in our press because we were able to force a lot of turnovers."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
